sentences.original: kayâs pêyak nâpêw iskwêwasâkay isiyîhkâsôw ayahciyiniw.
sentences.text: kayâs pêyak nâpêw iskwêwasâkay isiyîhkâsôw ayahciyiniw
sentences.english: Of old a certain Blackfoot was named Skirt.
He was poor.
Once upon a time he lay on a hilltop.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê wâpamêw iskwêwah êh-wayawiyit, ê-kî-nipahimiht onâpêmiyiwah, ê-ki-nipahikowit kâhkâkiwacêna.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê wâpamêw iskwêwa ê-wayawiyit ê-kî-nipahimiht onâpêmiyiwa ê-kî-nipahikoyit kâhkâkiwacêna
sentences.english: Presently he saw a woman come out of her lodge, a certain woman whose husband had been killed; the Crow Indians had killed him.
And so now this man took a fancy to her.
He saw her take an axe.
She was carrying her little son.
So now he went from where he was.

sentences.original: tah oma k-âyât, êkotah ohci pêc-âstamohtêw, wîkihk êh-ohci-sipwêhtêt an îskwêw.
sentences.text: ita ôma kâ-ayâ-t êkota ohci pêci-âstamohtêw wîkihk ê-ohci-sipwêhtêt ana iskwêw
sentences.english: Toward the place where he was, the woman came, when she left her tent.
So then the poor Blackfoot hid from her.
Then that woman looked out in every direction from the hilltop.

sentences.original: êkosi êk âwiyah êh-wâpamât, sipwêhtêw êkwah iskwêw ani.
sentences.text: êkosi êkâ awiya ê-wâpamât sipwêhtêw êkwa iskwêw ani
sentences.english: Then, when she saw no one, she went away.
As soon as she was round a bend, that man started out on a run.
When he got within sight of her, he hid from her.
As they thus went along, he saw a small clump of trees;
there the woman squatted down.
She laid her little son down at one side.

sentences.original: êkosi otinam cîkahikan; êkwah cîkaham asiskiy; êkwah wâtihkêw.
sentences.text: êkosi otinam cîkahikan êkwa cîkaham asiskiy êkwa wâtihkêw
sentences.english: Then she took the axe; she chopped at the ground; she dug a pit.

sentences.original: mâna awa nâpêw piyisk kisiwâk otihtêw awa nâpêw.
sentences.text: mâna awa nâpêw piyisk kisiwâk otihtêw awa nâpêw
sentences.english: After a time the man had got quite close to her.

sentences.original: êkwah awah iskwêw pasikôw; nanâtawâpiw; êkâ kêkway êh-wâpahtahk, kâwi nahapiw.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw pasikôw nanâtawâpiw êkâ kêkway ê-wâpahtahk kâwi nahapiw
sentences.english: Then the woman rose to her feet and looked about; when she saw nothing near, she squatted down again.
She went into the pit, digging for old wolflings.
sentences.footnote: LB on {mahîkhanisisah}:  The translation given is literal; either the record is wrong, or the word has some derived meaning (name of an edible root?)

sentences.english: She took one up; she flung it on the ground.
Then she went into the pit again.
At that, the man ran to where she was;
when she came forth again, he threw himself flat on the earth, hiding from her.
Again she entered the pit.
At once the man rose to his feet.

sentences.original: wâpamêw, otah iskoh, otêh isi êh-kwayasitêyit, ostikwâniyihk isi.
sentences.text: wâpamêw ôta isko ôtê isi ê-kwayasitêyit ostikwâniyihk isi
sentences.english: He saw that up to here, up to this point she was in the pit, up to her head.
Then he took this woman for his wife.

sentences.original: êkosi aw îskwêw ôtêh, miciminêw ôhi nâpêwa.
sentences.text: êkosi awa iskwêw ôtê miciminêw ôhi nâpêwa
sentences.english: Thereupon the woman took hold of the man here, like this.
Then she came forth from the pit;

sentences.original: êkosi otinêw okosisah; wîwahôw okosisah aw îskwêw.
sentences.text: êkosi otinêw okosisa wîwahôw okosisa awa iskwêw
sentences.english: she took up her son; the woman carried her son.
The man took his blanket-robe.
Then she took him home with her.
When he came to the town, the man stopped by a tent.
She pulled him on.

sentences.original: âstam! itêw iskwêw awah; âsay kônâpêmimitin.
sentences.english: “This way!” that woman said to him; “You are my husband now.”
So the man went on.

sentences.original: kîwêhtahik êkwah, pîhtiyisk êh-wîkit aw îskwêw.
sentences.text: kîwêhtahik êkwa pîhtêyask ê-wîkit awa iskwêw
sentences.english: She took him to her lodge; in the center of the camp dwelt that woman.
So she took him into her tent.
Then they took their seats on the settee of the man of the house.
She gave him that privilege.
She took some water.
She washed his hands and face.
Then she arose.
She went out; she stood in the doorway of her tent.
“Mother!” she called;

sentences.original: êkosi, astêw cî, nêkâ êh-kîsitêk wiyâs ?
sentences.english: “Mother, is there any cooked meat?”
“Yes!”
“Bring it here!” said the woman.
Then she came in again.
The old woman took some;
she went with it over to hed daughter's tent.
She opened the door-flap;
she gave it to her daughter.
She saw the man sitting on her daughter's settee.

sentences.original: êkosi kîwêw awa nôtokêsiw; pîhtokêw wîkihk.
sentences.text: êkosi kîwêw awa nôtokêsiw pîhtokêw wîkihk
sentences.english: Thereupon the old woman went back; she went into her lodge.
She told her husband of it: “It is that our daughter is sitting by the side of a man.”
“Who is he?” the old man asked her.

sentences.original: êkosi awa nôtokêsiw, êyakonih kâ-kitimâkisiyit nâpêwa.
sentences.english: Then the old woman, “That poor man.”

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah kisêyiniw awa êh-okimâwit, pêyakoyiwa okosisah;
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa kisêyiniw awa ê-okimâwit pêyakoyiwa okosisa
sentences.english: Now, that old man, who was a chief, had one son;

sentences.original: êkwah ôhi k-ôtinamâsoyit nâpêwa, êyakonih otânisa.
sentences.text: êkwa ôhi kâ-otinamâsoyit nâpêwa êwakoni otânisa
sentences.english: and she who had taken that man, she was his daughter.

sentences.original: êkosi nîso pikoh otawâsimisah awa kisêyiniw mînah nôtokêsiw.
sentences.text: êkosi nîso piko otawâsimisa awa kisêyiniw mîna nôtokêsiw
sentences.english: Only these two children had that old man and old woman.

sentences.original: êkosi nama wîhkâc wayawîw awa kâ-kitimâkisit nâpêw;
sentences.text: êkosi nama wîhkâc wayawîw awa kâ-kitimâkisit nâpêw
sentences.english: And now that poor man never went out of their tent;
he was ashamed.
Then at one time. “Let us move camp!” said his people.
This was when he had been married for quite some time.

sentences.original: êkosi mistahi miyosiw awa nâpêw kâ-wîwit, mâka mistahi êh-kitimâkisit.
sentences.text: êkosi mistahi miyosiw awa nâpêw kâ-wîwit mâka mistahi ê-kitimâkisit
sentences.english: Now, that man who had married the woman, was very good-looking, only that he was very poor.
So now, early one morning, he went out of the tent.

sentences.original: êkosi sipwêhtêw, kont îtê êh-itohtêt, êh-osâm êh-nêpêwisit, mistahi êh-kitimâkisit.
sentences.text: êkosi sipwêhtêw konita itê ê-itohtêt ê-osâm ê-nêpêwisit mistahi ê-kitimâkisit
sentences.english: He went away, no matter where, for very shame at his great poverty.

sentences.original: êkosi aw ôskinîkiw omisah k-ônâpêmiyit ayâw êh-miywâsiniyikih ayôwinisah;
sentences.text: êkosi awa oskinîkiw omisa kâ-onâpêmiyit ayâw ê-miywâsiniyiki ayiwinisa
sentences.english: Now, that young man whose elder sister had taken that man for husband, had some fine clothes;
his horse, too, was very handsome.

sentences.original: êkwah awa nâpêw oskinîkiw otinêw wîstâwa otêmiyiwa; wiyahpitêw aspapiwin ohci.
sentences.text: êkwa awa nâpêw oskinîkiw otinêw wîstâwa otêmiyiwa wiyahpitêw aspapiwin ohci
sentences.english: Then that young man took his brother-in-law's horse and saddled it.
sentences.footnote: LB on {wîstâwa}: I.e., of his sister's first husband.

sentences.original: wîhtamawêw okâwiya : anihi k-âyât nimis ayôwinisah êkosi ta-pêtâw nimis.
sentences.english: He told his mother his plan: “Those garments which my elder sister is keeping, let her bring them here.
But where has my brother-in-law gone?”

sentences.original: aspin ôtê êh-kîh-atimohtêt, itwêw awa oskinîkiskwêw.
sentences.english: “He has gone off and away in this direction,” said the young woman.

sentences.original: êkosi nâpêw awa oskinîkiw otinêw misatimwah;
sentences.text: êkosi nâpêw awa oskinîkiw otinêw misatimwa
sentences.english: Thereupon the young man took the horse;

sentences.original: ôhi ayôwinisah tahkopitam, êkwah akohp êh-mîkisiwiyik.
sentences.text: ôhi ayiwinisa tahkopitam êkwa akohp ê-mîkisiwiyik
sentences.english: he tied those garments  to the saddle, and a blanket-robe with bead ornaments.
Then he mounted;

sentences.original: sakâpêkipahêw ôhi kâ-nayahcikêyit, êkwah êh-ntonawât wîstâwah.
sentences.text: sakâpêkipahêw ôhi kâ-nayahcikêyit êkwa ê-nitonawât wîstâwa
sentences.english: at a trot he led the horse that was carrying the things, as he looked for his brother-in-law.

sentences.original: aspin wiya êh-wawêyîwiht, ê-wîh-piciwiht, êy-osêhcâyik sâkêwêw êwakô awa oskinîkiw, kâ-ntonawât wîstâwa.
sentences.text: aspin wiya ê-wawêyîwiht ê-wî-piciwiht ê-osêhcâyik sâkêwêw êwako awa oskinîkiw kâ-nitonawât wîstâwa
sentences.english: Just as his people were making ready to move camp, off went that youth, over the hill, to look for his brother-in-law.
He found him where he lay on the ground.
So there he dismounted.

sentences.original: êkosi wîstâwah, waniskâh, nîstah! itêw awa oskinîkiw.
sentences.english: Then to his brother-in-law, “Get up, Brother-in-Law!” said that youth.
So Skirt arose.
Then he took his brother-in-law's garments;
he put other, handsome ones, on his brother-in-law.

sentences.original: êkwah sîkahwêw ôhi mitonih êh-kinwâyikih wêstakayiyiwah.
sentences.text: êkwa sîkahwêw ôhi mitoni ê-kinwâyiki wêstakayiyiwa
sentences.english: Then he combed him, for very long was his hair.
When he had combed his  brother-in-law's hair, he washed his face for him.
When he had  washed his face, he painted his face for him.
Then, “Brother-in-Law, I love you very much.

sentences.original: êkâ wiya ê-ntohtawakik oskinîkiwak, mihcêtwâw nntotamâkawin, êh-kîh-itêyihtamân.
sentences.english: I did not listen when time after time I was besought, for I thought, 'When my sister likes any one, then let her take a husband.'
And so she liked you.
Do not be ashamed.
And now let us depart.

sentences.original: êkosi kit-âyâwat nîstâw otêma, anah kâ-kîh-nipahiht.
sentences.english: You shall now have the horse of my brother-in-law, the one who was slain.”
Then they arose.
They set out.

sentences.original: mistahi miyosiw awa kaskitêwastim kâ-têhtapit awa kâ-kitimâkisit.
sentences.text: mistahi miyosiw awa kaskitêwastim kâ-têhtapit awa kâ-kitimâkisit
sentences.english: Very handsome was the black horse which the poor man rode.

sentences.original: tâpwê êh-pimohtêcik awa oskinîkiw, tâpwê mistahi miyosiw nîstâw! itêyihtam awa oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-pimohtêcik awa oskinîkiw itêyihtam awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: As they went along, “Truly, very handsome is my brother-in-law!” thought that youth.

sentences.original: ôhih mitâsah mistahi mîkisak kikamôwak, êkwah omatôwah mêstakayah mînah.
sentences.text: ôhi mitâsa mistahi mîkisak kikamôwak êkwa ômatôwahk mêstakaya mîna
sentences.english: On those leggings were many beads, and these things, scalps, as well.

sentences.original: miskotâkay mistahi mîkisiyiwa; êwakô kikasâkêw awa kâ-wîwit.
sentences.text: miskotâkay mistahi mîkisiyiwa êwako kikasâkêw awa kâ-wîwit
sentences.english: The coat was heavily beaded; he wore it, who had married the woman.

sentences.original: êkwah nikikwayân êkotôwahk otastotiniw awa kâ-wîwit.
sentences.text: êkwa nikikwayân êkotôwahk otastotiniw awa kâ-wîwit
sentences.english: And an otterskin he had as his hat, he who had married the woman.
Then, in the afternoon, when they came in sight of the place, their people had already pitched camp.
They came down the slope, the two brothers-in-law.

sentences.original: êkwah aw îskwêw, êh-pêtisâpamât onâpêma, tâpwê miyosiw ninâpêm! itêyihtam awa iskwêw.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw ê-pêtisâpamât onâpêma itêyihtam awa iskwêw
sentences.english: Then that woman, when she saw her husband approaching, “Truly, handsome is my husband!” thought that woman.
So they came to their tent.
He dismounted.
Then the woman came out of the tent.
“Come in!” she said to her husband.
The man went in.

sentences.original: êkwah aw îskwêw âpahwêw ôhi misatimwa.
sentences.text: êkwa awa iskwêw âpahwêw ôhi misatimwa
sentences.english: Then the woman unsaddled the horse.
She tied it up.
Then she came in.
She sat down by her husband.
She took food and gave him to eat.
When he had eaten, at nightfall,  she went out.
Her husband went with her.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pikw îsi mêtawâkâtâw awa oskinîkiw, êh-ohtêyimiht, okimâskwêwa êh-wîwit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê piko isi mêtawâkâtâw awa oskinîkiw ê-ohtêyimiht okimâskwêwa ê-wîwit
sentences.english: Then at one time, in one way or another, people teased that young man, because they were jealous of his having married a chief's  daughter.
They would say this thing and that to him.
“Pay no attention to it.

sentences.original: mihcêtwâw pikw âwiyak nkîh-nôhtê-wîkimik, mâka nama wiya êy-ôhci-nôhtê-onâpêmiyân.
sentences.english: Many times more than one of them wanted to marry me, and it was only that I did not want to marry them.

sentences.original: êkâ wiya wîhkâc nitohtah pikw îsi êh-itikawiyin; êh-ohtêyimikawiyan, mihcêt nâpêwak êh-kî-nôhtê-wîkimicik.
sentences.english: Do you never listen when they say foolish things to you, for it is only that you are envied, because many men wanted to marry me.”
Then at one time he heard, “Some foreign folk have been seen.”

sentences.original: êkosi wîstâwah, êkâ wiyah nânitaw t-êtohtêw;
sentences.english: Then his brother-in-law said. “Let him not go, you know where;
I love my brother-in-law and would keep him.”

sentences.original: êkosi tâpwê nama wiya pakitinik wîwa.
sentences.text: êkosi tâpwê nama wiya pakitinik wîwa
sentences.english: Accordingly his wife did not let him go from her.

sentences.original: êkosi kotakak êh-kîskotâtocik, ôtah pêmipayitwâwi, nam êskwa kikîskotâton.
sentences.english: So then, whenever the others went out to the attack, as they went past there, “Not yet have you gone to the attack.

sentences.original: âsay mihcêt kitôskinîkîmak, itik ôhi kâ-pimipayiyit.
sentences.english: Already many of your men have gone,” they who rode past said to him.
sentences.footnote: LB on quote: Apparently I missed the verb.

sentences.original: êkwah ê-sîkawiwiht, mahtih nâs nitêm, itêw ôhi wîwah.
sentences.english: Then when some of his people had lost their kin, “Suppose you fetch my horse,” he bade his wife.
“'Do not let him depart,' my brother said of you,” his wife replied to him.
“Just you fetch my horse,” he told his wife.

sentences.original: êkosi nâtêw awa iskwêw ôhi kaskitêwastimwa.
sentences.text: êkosi nâtêw awa iskwêw ôhi kaskitêwastimwa
sentences.english: So then the woman went and got that black horse.

sentences.original: êkosi wiyahpitêyiwa ôhi otêma; pîhtokêyiwa wîwa.
sentences.text: êkosi wiyahpitêyiwa ôhi otêma pîhtokêyiwa wîwa
sentences.english: Then she saddled his horse and came into the tent.
Then he undressed;
he kept on only his breech-clout.

sentences.original: osâw-asiskiy misiwê wiyawihk sinikohtitâw, misiwê êy-osâwaskiwastêt êwakô.
sentences.text: osâwi-asiskiy misiwê wiyawihk sinikohtitâw misiwê ê-osâwasiskîwastêt êwako
sentences.english: He rubbed ochre all over his body; he covered himself with yellow clay.
Then his mother-in-law came hither.
“Why have you saddled my son-in-law's horse?”

sentences.original: êy-isit awa, itêw okâwiyah awa iskwêw.
sentences.english: “Because he bade me saddle it,” the woman answered her mother.

sentences.original: kikîh-kitahamâk kisîmis kitah-sipwêhtêt nnahâhkisîm, itwêw awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.english: “Your brother forbade you to let my son-in-law depart,” said the old woman.
Then the man undid his hair;
he tied it in a knot at the back.
His wife tended to him; she painted his face.
A spear he took.

sentences.original: êkosi astotn, sihkosiwayân-astotn êyakô, êskanak kikamôwak astotinihk.
sentences.text: êkosi astotin sihkosiwayân-astotin êwako êskanak kikamôwak astotinihk
sentences.english: Also a head-dress, a head-dress of weaselskin; horns were fastened on it.
As he left the tent, his wife kissed him.
“Daughter, do not let my son-in-law throw his life away.

sentences.original: mistahi sâkihik wîstâwah mîna osisah, itêw awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.english: His brother-in-law and his father-in-law love him dearly,” said the old woman to her.
Then he leaped on his horse.
Then he made the circuit of the town.
“On this day you shall speak my name.
If I live, you will be content to say 'Skirt,' if I live,” he said.
With that he rode away.
As he rode over the hill, he saw the men going yon way.

sentences.original: êkosi êtimâci mân êkwah, kikîsiskotâtow itik nâpêwah.
sentences.text: êkosi êtimâci mâna êkwa itik nâpêwa
sentences.english: And so, as he overtook them, “You are going to the attack, are you?” the men would say to him.

sentences.original: êy-osêhcâk atimâpêmêw, ê-sâkêwêpayiyit wîstâwa êkwah osisa.
sentences.text: ê-osêhcâk atimâpamêw ê-sâkêwêpayiyit wîstâwa êkwa osisa
sentences.english: From a rise in the land he saw his brother-in-law and his father-in-law riding across a ridge.

sentences.original: êh-at-âtimât osisah, hâw, nnahâhkisîm, kakwê-pimâtisih! itik omanâcimâkanah.
sentences.english: When he overtook his father-in-law, “Now, my son-in-law, try to preserve your life!” said his tabu-person to him.

sentences.original: êh-atimât wîstâwah, âh, nîstah, mistahi kisâkihitn itik wîstâwah.
sentences.english: When he overtook his brother-in-law, “Oh, my brother-in-law, dearly do I love you!” his brother-in-law said to him.

sentences.original: êkosi kitâpamêw : hâh, nîsta, kisâkihitn nîstah! itêw wîstâwa.
sentences.english: Thereupon he fixed his gaze on him: “Oh, my brother-in-law, I too love you!” he told his brother-in-law.
With that he passed his brother-in-law and went on.
One man always rode about in the rear of the rest;
he was mounted on a little white horse.
Just as he overtook this man, the latter shot at him.
When one was left behind, he felled him with his spear.
Then he would come up to him, and stab him;
at last he had killed nine men.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk êkwah tapasiyiwa ôhi wâpascimosah kâ-têhtapiyit.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk êkwa tapasîyiwa ôhi wâpascimosa kâ-têhtapiyit
sentences.english: By this time the rider of the small white horse was fleeing.
He pursued him.
When he overtook him, the other shot at him;
here on his cheek the other grazed him with a shot.
Then he seized hold of the other's horse.
“Dismount!” he told the stranger.
So the other dismounted.
“Give me your gunl” he said to him.
So he gave it to him.
“Give me your knife!” he told him.
The other gave it to him.
“And your ammunition-bag!”
So the other gave him everything.
“And your head-dress!” - for the other had a headgear of feathers.
Then, “Give me your horse!” he told him.
So the other gave it to him.

sentences.original: hâw, awa têhtapih, itêw, ôhi kaskitêwastimwah mîskoc êyakonih êh-miyât;
sentences.text: itêw ôhi kaskitêwastimwa mîskoc êwakoni ê-miyât
sentences.english: “There, now mount this one,” he told him giving him the black horse in return;
“It is very swift;
no one will overtake you.

sentences.original: takosiniyani kitaskiwâhk, kitah-âcimowin; êyak ohci k-ôh-itêyimitân.
sentences.english: When you arrive in your people's country, that you may tell the tale; that is the reason why 'May he live!' is my thought concerning  you.”
So he mounted.

sentences.original: êwako awa miyêw otastotin, sihkosiwayân-astotin awa ayahciyiniw, êkwah câpihcicikanis.
sentences.text: êwako awa miyêw otastotin sihkosiwayân-astotin awa ayahciyiniw êkwa câpihcicikanis
sentences.english: Then he gave him his head-dress, the headdress  of weaselskin, did that Blackfoot, and the spear.
he one whose life was spared was called Crow.
So then he fled.
Then that Blackfoot's brother-in-law came up to him.
This brother-in-law was very sorry that he had been wounded in the face.
So then they went home.

sentences.original: at-ôtinêw kahkiyaw misatimwa awa kisêyiniw, onahâhkisîma tahtoh kâ-pê-nipahâyit, mîna otayôwinisiyiwa, mîna onîmâskwâkaniyiwa.
sentences.text: ati-otinêw kahkiyaw misatimwa awa kisêyiniw onahâhkisîma tahto kâ-pê-nipahâyit mîna otayiwinisiyiwa mîna onîmâskwâkaniyiwa
sentences.english: The old man, as he went along, took all the horses of as many as were the men his son-in-law had slain, and their garments, and their weapons.
So then they all went home.

sentences.original: ê-wîh-takohtêcik, wâhyaw nîkân pimohtêw awa iskwêwasâkay, êwakô, êh-ati-sâkêwêcik.
sentences.text: ê-wî-takohtêcik wâhyaw nîkân pimohtêw awa iskwêwasâkay êwako ê-ati-sâkêwêcik
sentences.english: When they had almost arrived, then far ahead went Skirt, as they came into view.

sentences.original: namoya kîh-âkwâskiskawâw, osâm mistah êh-tôtahk; âsay kaskihisôw êh-okimâwit.
sentences.text: namôya kî-âkwaskiskawâw osâm mistahi ê-tôtahk âsay kaskihisôw ê-okimâwit
sentences.english: No one was permitted to go ahead of him, on account of the great deeds he had done; he had now won the chieftainship.

sentences.original: êkos îsi kahkiyaw ayahciyiniwak mistahi kostik, êh-wâpamiht, mistah êh-pâskisoht, êkosi êkâ êh-pihkwahoht.
sentences.text: êkosi isi kahkiyaw ayahciyiniwak mistahi kostik ê-wâpamiht mistahi ê-pâskisoht êkosi êkâ ê-pikwâhoht
sentences.english: So then he was greatly respected by all the Blackfoot, when it was seen that he had been much shot at and not seriously wounded.
When the other chiefs thought of that, they greatly respected him.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc pêtamâsôw ta-mîcit, pikoh êh-pêtamâht.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc pêtamâsôw ta-mîcit piko ê-pêtamâht
sentences.english: Never did he need to fetch his food, for always others brought it to him.
And his brother-in-law was very fond of him.
And so he became a great chief.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-nipit, okosisah kîh-okimâwiyiwa, êwakô anah kotak ôhtâwiyah kâ-nipiyit.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-nipit okosisa kî-okimâwiyiwa êwako ana kotak ôhtâwiya kâ-nipiyit
sentences.english: And then, when he died, his son became chief, the son of the other man who had died.
Black-Weasel was his name.
That is all.
